Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I could feel my phone buzzing in my pocket as I finished rinsing the dye from my client’s hair. My boyfriend’s name flashed on the screen, and I knew it was about our fight last night—the one where we both said things we couldn’t take back. He wanted to talk, to fix things, but I was at work, scissors in hand, and a new client sat in my chair, frowning at her reflection. She hesitated, then said, “It’s not quite what I expected. Can we fix the colour?” My heart pounded. I was supposed to be calm, attentive, and professional, but my mind was tangled in the words from his last message: “Are we even right for each other?” I wanted to step outside, call him, and try to resolve everything before it slipped away. But my client needed me now, expecting reassurance and a solution. I stood there, torn, the weight of both worlds pressing down, unsure which voice to answer first.
